member.summary: Indicates the string containing the URL of the font designer (with protocol, e.g., http://, ftp://).

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.Description
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the description of the font. This may also contain revision information, usage recommendations, history, features, etc.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.FontVendorUrl
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the URL of the font vendor (with protocol, e.g., http://, ftp://). If a unique serial number is embedded in the URL, it can be used to register the font.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.LicenseDescription
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the description of how the font may be legally used, or different example scenarios for licensed use.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.LicenseInformationUrl
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the URL where additional licensing information can be found.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.Win32FamilyNames
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the GDI-compatible family name. Since GDI allows a maximum of four fonts per family, fonts in the same family may have different GDI-compatible family names (e.g., "Arial", "Arial Narrow", "Arial Black").

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.Win32SubfamilyNames
member.summary: Indicates the string containing a GDI-compatible subfamily name.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.PreferredFamilyNames
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the family name preferred by the designer. This enables font designers to group more than four fonts in a single family without losing compatibility with GDI. This name is typically only present if it differs from the GDI-compatible family name.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.PreferredSubfamilyNames
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the subfamily name preferred by the designer. This name is typically only present if it differs from the GDI-compatible subfamily name.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InformationalStringId.SampleText
member.summary: Contains sample text for display in font lists. This can be the font name or any other text that the designer thinks is the best example to display the font in.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FactoryType
member.summary: Specifies the type of DirectWrite factory object.
member.remarks: A DirectWrite factory object contains information about its internal state, such as font loader registration and cached font data. In most cases you should use the shared factory object, because it allows multiple components that use DirectWrite to share internal DirectWrite state information, thereby reducing memory usage. However, there are cases when it is desirable to reduce the impact of a component on the rest of the process, such as a plug-in from an untrusted source, by sandboxing and isolating it from the rest of the process components. In such cases, you should use an isolated factory for the sandboxed component.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FactoryType.Shared
member.summary: Indicates that the DirectWrite factory is a shared factory and that it allows for the reuse of cached font data across multiple in-process components. Such factories also take advantage of cross process font caching components for better performance.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FactoryType.Isolated
member.summary: Indicates that the DirectWrite factory object is isolated. Objects created from the isolated factory do not interact with internal DirectWrite state from other components.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry
member.summary: Represents the internal structure of a device pixel (that is the physical arrangement of red, green, and blue color components) that is assumed for purposes of rendering text.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry.Flat
member.summary: The red, green, and blue color components of each pixel are assumed to occupy the same point.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry.Rgb
member.summary: Each pixel is composed of three vertical stripes, with red on the left, green in the center, and blue on the right. This is the most common pixel geometry for LCD monitors.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry.Bgr
member.summary: Each pixel is composed of three vertical stripes, with blue on the left, green in the center, and red on the right.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode
member.summary: Represents a method of rendering glyphs.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.Default
member.summary: Specifies that the rendering mode is determined automatically, based on the font and size.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.Aliased
member.summary: Specifies that no anti-aliasing is performed. Each pixel is either set to the foreground color of the text or retains the color of the background.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.CleartypeGdiClassic
member.summary: Specifies ClearType rendering with the same metrics as bi-level text. Glyphs can only be positioned on whole-pixel boundaries.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.CleartypeGdiNatural
member.summary: Specifies ClearType rendering with the same metrics as text rendering using GDI using a font created with CLEARTYPE_NATURAL_QUALITY. Glyph metrics are closer to their ideal values than with bi-level text, but glyphs are still positioned on whole-pixel boundaries.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.CleartypeNatural
member.summary: Specifies ClearType rendering with anti-aliasing in the horizontal dimension only. This is typically used with small to medium font sizes (up to 16 ppem).

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.CleartypeNaturalSymmetric
member.summary: Specifies ClearType rendering with anti-aliasing in both horizontal and vertical dimensions. This is typically used at larger sizes to makes curves and diagonal lines look smoother, at the expense of some softness.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.RenderingMode.Outline
member.summary: Specifies that rendering should bypass the rasterizer and use the outlines directly. This is typically used at very large sizes.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ReadingDirection
member.summary: Specifies the direction in which reading progresses.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ReadingDirection.LeftToRight
member.summary: Indicates that reading progresses from left to right.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ReadingDirection.RightToLeft
member.summary: Indicates that reading progresses from right to left.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FlowDirection
member.summary: Indicates the direction of flow for placing lines of text in a paragraph.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FlowDirection.TopToBottom
member.summary: Specifies that text lines are placed from top to bottom.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextAlignment
member.summary: Specifies the alignment of paragraph text along the reading direction axis, relative to the leading and trailing edge of the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextAlignment.Leading
member.summary: The leading edge of the paragraph text is aligned to the leading edge of the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextAlignment.Trailing
member.summary: The trailing edge of the paragraph text is aligned to the trailing edge of the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextAlignment.Center
member.summary: The center of the paragraph text is aligned to the center of the layout box.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment
member.summary: Specifies the alignment of paragraph text along the flow direction axis, relative to the top and bottom of the flow's layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment.Near
member.summary: The top of the text flow is aligned to the top edge of the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment.Far
member.summary: The bottom of the text flow is aligned to the bottom edge of the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment.Center
member.summary: The center of the flow is aligned to the center of the layout box.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.WordWrapping
member.summary: Specifies the word wrapping to be used in a particular multiline paragraph.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.WordWrapping.Wrap
member.summary: Indicates that words are broken across lines to avoid text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.WordWrapping.NoWrap
member.summary: Indicates that words are kept within the same line even when it overflows the layout box. This option is often used with scrolling to reveal overflow text.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.LineSpacingMethod
member.summary: The method used for line spacing in a text layout.
member.remarks: The line spacing method is set by using the {{SetLineSpacing}} method of the or interfaces. To get the current line spacing method of a text format or text layou use the {{GetLineSpacing}}.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.LineSpacingMethod.Default
member.summary: Line spacing depends solely on the content, adjusting to accommodate the size of fonts and inline objects.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.LineSpacingMethod.Uniform
member.summary: Lines are explicitly set to uniform spacing, regardless of the size of fonts and inline objects. This can be useful to avoid the uneven appearance that can occur from font fallback.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity
member.summary: Specifies the text granularity used to trim text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity.None
member.summary: No trimming occurs. Text flows beyond the layout width.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity.Character
member.summary: Trimming occurs at a character cluster boundary.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity.Word
member.summary: Trimming occurs at a word boundary.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag
member.summary: A value that indicates the typographic feature of text supplied by the font.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.AlternativeFractions
member.summary: Replaces figures separated by a slash with an alternative form. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'afrc'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.PetiteCapitalsFromCapitals
member.summary: Turns capital characters into petite capitals. It is generally used for words which would otherwise be set in all caps, such as acronyms, but which are desired in petite-cap form to avoid disrupting the flow of text. See the pcap feature description for notes on the relationship of caps, smallcaps and petite caps. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'c2pc'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.SmallCapitalsFromCapitals
member.summary: Turns capital characters into small capitals. It is generally used for words which would otherwise be set in all caps, such as acronyms, but which are desired in small-cap form to avoid disrupting the flow of text. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'c2sc'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.ContextualAlternates
member.summary: In specified situations, replaces default glyphs with alternate forms which provide better joining behavior. Used in script typefaces which are designed to have some or all of their glyphs join. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'calt'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.CaseSensitiveForms
member.summary: Shifts various punctuation marks up to a position that works better with all-capital sequences or sets of lining figures; also changes oldstyle figures to lining figures. By default, glyphs in a text face are designed to work with lowercase characters. Some characters should be shifted vertically to fit the higher visual center of all-capital or lining text. Also, lining figures are the same height (or close to it) as capitals, and fit much better with all-capital text. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'case'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.GlyphCompositionDecomposition
member.summary: To minimize the number of glyph alternates, it is sometimes desired to decompose a character into two glyphs. Additionally, it may be preferable to compose two characters into a single glyph for better glyph processing. This feature permits such composition/decomposition. The feature should be processed as the first feature processed, and should be processed only when it is called. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ccmp'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.ContextualLigatures
member.summary: Replaces a sequence of glyphs with a single glyph which is preferred for typographic purposes. Unlike other ligature features, clig specifies the context in which the ligature is recommended. This capability is important in some script designs and for swash ligatures. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'clig'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.CapitalSpacing
member.summary: Globally adjusts inter-glyph spacing for all-capital text. Most typefaces contain capitals and lowercase characters, and the capitals are positioned to work with the lowercase. When capitals are used for words, they need more space between them for legibility and esthetics. This feature would not apply to monospaced designs. Of course the user may want to override this behavior in order to do more pronounced letterspacing for esthetic reasons. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'cpsp'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.ContextualSwash
member.summary: Replaces default character glyphs with corresponding swash glyphs in a specified context. Note that there may be more than one swash alternate for a given character. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'cswh'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.CursivePositioning
member.summary: In cursive scripts like Arabic, this feature cursively positions adjacent glyphs. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'curs'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Default
member.summary: Replaces a sequence of glyphs with a single glyph which is preferred for typographic purposes. This feature covers those ligatures which may be used for special effect, at the user's preference. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'dlig'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.DiscretionaryLigatures
member.summary: Replaces standard forms in Japanese fonts with corresponding forms preferred by typographers. For example, a user would invoke this feature to replace kanji character U+5516 with U+555E. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'expt'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.ExpertForms
member.summary: Replaces figures separated by a slash with 'common' (diagonal) fractions. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'frac'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Fractions
member.summary: Replaces glyphs set on other widths with glyphs set on full (usually em) widths. In a CJKV font, this may include "lower ASCII" Latin characters and various symbols. In a European font, this feature replaces proportionally-spaced glyphs with monospaced glyphs, which are generally set on widths of 0.6 em. For example, a user may invoke this feature in a Japanese font to get full monospaced Latin glyphs instead of the corresponding proportionally-spaced versions. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'fwid'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.FullWidth
member.summary: Produces the half forms of consonants in Indic scripts. For example, in Hindi (Devanagari script), the conjunct KKa, obtained by doubling the Ka, is denoted with a half form of Ka followed by the full form. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'half'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.HalfForms
member.summary: Produces the halant forms of consonants in Indic scripts. For example, in Sanskrit (Devanagari script), syllable final consonants are frequently required in their halant form. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'haln'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.HalantForms
member.summary: Respaces glyphs designed to be set on full-em widths, fitting them onto half-em widths. This differs from hwid in that it does not substitute new glyphs. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'halt'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.AlternateHalfWidth
member.summary: Replaces the default (current) forms with the historical alternates. While some ligatures are also used for historical effect, this feature deals only with single characters. Some fonts include the historical forms as alternates, so they can be used for a 'period' effect. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'hist'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.HistoricalForms
member.summary: Replaces standard kana with forms that have been specially designed for only horizontal writing. This is a typographic optimization for improved fit and more even color. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'hkna'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.HorizontalKanaAlternates
member.summary: Replaces the default (current) forms with the historical alternates. Some ligatures were in common use in the past, but appear anachronistic today. Some fonts include the historical forms as alternates, so they can be used for a 'period' effect. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'hlig'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.HistoricalLigatures
member.summary: Replaces glyphs on proportional widths, or fixed widths other than half an em, with glyphs on half-em (en) widths. Many CJKV fonts have glyphs which are set on multiple widths; this feature selects the half-em version. There are various contexts in which this is the preferred behavior, including compatibility with older desktop documents. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'hwid'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.HalfWidth
member.summary: Used to access the JIS X 0212-1990 glyphs for the cases when the JIS X 0213:2004 form is encoded. The JIS X 0212-1990 (aka, "Hojo Kanji") and JIS X 0213:2004 character sets overlap significantly. In some cases their prototypical glyphs differ. When building fonts that support both JIS X 0212-1990 and JIS X 0213:2004 (such as those supporting the Adobe-Japan 1-6 character collection), it is recommended that JIS X 0213:2004 forms be the preferred encoded form. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'hojo'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.HojoKanjiForms
member.summary: The National Language Council (NLC) of Japan has defined new glyph shapes for a number of JIS characters, which were incorporated into JIS X 0213:2004 as new prototypical forms. The 'jp04' feature is A subset of the 'nlck' feature, and is used to access these prototypical glyphs in a manner that maintains the integrity of JIS X 0213:2004. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'jp04'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Jis04Forms
member.summary: Replaces default (JIS90) Japanese glyphs with the corresponding forms from the JIS C 6226-1978 (JIS78) specification. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'jp78'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Jis78Forms
member.summary: Replaces default (JIS90) Japanese glyphs with the corresponding forms from the JIS X 0208-1983 (JIS83) specification. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'jp83'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Jis83Forms
member.summary: Replaces Japanese glyphs from the JIS78 or JIS83 specifications with the corresponding forms from the JIS X 0208-1990 (JIS90) specification. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'jp90'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Jis90Forms
member.summary: Adjusts amount of space between glyphs, generally to provide optically consistent spacing between glyphs. Although a well-designed typeface has consistent inter-glyph spacing overall, some glyph combinations require adjustment for improved legibility. Besides standard adjustment in the horizontal direction, this feature can supply size-dependent kerning data via device tables, "cross-stream" kerning in the Y text direction, and adjustment of glyph placement independent of the advance adjustment. Note that this feature may apply to runs of more than two glyphs, and would not be used in monospaced fonts. Also note that this feature does not apply to text set vertically. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'kern'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Kerning
member.summary: Replaces a sequence of glyphs with a single glyph which is preferred for typographic purposes. This feature covers the ligatures which the designer/manufacturer judges should be used in normal conditions. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'liga'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StandardLigatures
member.summary: Changes selected figures from oldstyle to the default lining form. For example, a user may invoke this feature in order to get lining figures, which fit better with all-capital text. This feature overrides results of the Oldstyle Figures feature (onum). Equivalent OpenType tag: 'lnum'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.LiningFigures
member.summary: Enables localized forms of glyphs to be substituted for default forms. Many scripts used to write multiple languages over wide geographical areas have developed localized variant forms of specific letters, which are used by individual literary communities. For example, a number of letters in the Bulgarian and Serbian alphabets have forms distinct from their Russian counterparts and from each other. In some cases the localized form differs only subtly from the script 'norm', in others the forms are radically distinct. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'locl'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.LocalizedForms
member.summary: Positions mark glyphs with respect to base glyphs. For example, in Arabic script positioning the Hamza above the Yeh. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'mark'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.MarkPositioning
member.summary: Replaces standard typographic forms of Greek glyphs with corresponding forms commonly used in mathematical notation (which are a subset of the Greek alphabet). Equivalent OpenType tag: 'mgrk'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.MathematicalGreek
member.summary: Positions marks with respect to other marks. Required in various non-Latin scripts like Arabic. For example, in Arabic, the ligaturised mark Ha with Hamza above it can also be obtained by positioning these marks relative to one another. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'mkmk'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.MarkToMarkPositioning
member.summary: Replaces default glyphs with various notational forms (such as glyphs placed in open or solid circles, squares, parentheses, diamonds or rounded boxes). In some cases an annotation form may already be present, but the user may want a different one. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'nalt'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.AlternateAnnotationForms
member.summary: Used to access glyphs made from glyph shapes defined by the National Language Council (NLC) of Japan for a number of JIS characters in 2000. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'nlck'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.NlcKanjiForms
member.summary: Changes selected figures from the default lining style to oldstyle form. For example, a user may invoke this feature to get oldstyle figures, which fit better into the flow of normal upper- and lowercase text. This feature overrides results of the Lining Figures feature (lnum). Equivalent OpenType tag: 'onum'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.OldStyleFigures
member.summary: Replaces default alphabetic glyphs with the corresponding ordinal forms for use after figures. One exception to the follows-a-figure rule is the numero character (U+2116), which is actually a ligature substitution, but is best accessed through this feature. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ordn'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Ordinals
member.summary: Respaces glyphs designed to be set on full-em widths, fitting them onto individual (more or less proportional) horizontal widths. This differs from pwid in that it does not substitute new glyphs (GPOS, not GSUB feature). The user may prefer the monospaced form, or may simply want to ensure that the glyph is well-fit and not rotated in vertical setting (Latin forms designed for proportional spacing would be rotated). Equivalent OpenType tag: 'palt'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.ProportionalAlternateWidth
member.summary: Turns lowercase characters into petite capitals. Forms related to petite capitals, such as specially designed figures, may be included. Some fonts contain an additional size of capital letters, shorter than the regular smallcaps and it is referred to as petite caps. Such forms are most likely to be found in designs with a small lowercase x-height, where they better harmonise with lowercase text than the taller smallcaps (for examples of petite caps, see the Emigre type families Mrs Eaves and Filosofia). Equivalent OpenType tag: 'pcap'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.PetiteCapitals
member.summary: Replaces figure glyphs set on uniform (tabular) widths with corresponding glyphs set on glyph-specific (proportional) widths. Tabular widths will generally be the default, but this cannot be safely assumed. Of course this feature would not be present in monospaced designs. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'pnum'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.ProportionalFigures
member.summary: Replaces glyphs set on uniform widths (typically full or half-em) with proportionally spaced glyphs. The proportional variants are often used for the Latin characters in CJKV fonts, but may also be used for Kana in Japanese fonts. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'pwid'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.ProportionalWidths
member.summary: Replaces glyphs on other widths with glyphs set on widths of one quarter of an em (half an en). The characters involved are normally figures and some forms of punctuation. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'qwid'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.QuarterWidths
member.summary: Replaces a sequence of glyphs with a single glyph which is preferred for typographic purposes. This feature covers those ligatures, which the script determines as required to be used in normal conditions. This feature is important for some scripts to ensure correct glyph formation. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'rlig'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.RequiredLigatures
member.summary: Identifies glyphs in the font which have been designed for "ruby", from the old typesetting term for four-point-sized type. Japanese typesetting often uses smaller kana glyphs, generally in superscripted form, to clarify the meaning of kanji which may be unfamiliar to the reader. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ruby'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.RubyNotationForms
member.summary: Replaces the default forms with the stylistic alternates. Many fonts contain alternate glyph designs for a purely esthetic effect; these don't always fit into a clear category like swash or historical. As in the case of swash glyphs, there may be more than one alternate form. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'salt'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticAlternates
member.summary: Replaces lining or oldstyle figures with inferior figures (smaller glyphs which sit lower than the standard baseline, primarily for chemical or mathematical notation). May also replace lowercase characters with alphabetic inferiors. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'sinf'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.ScientificInferiors
member.summary: Turns lowercase characters into small capitals. This corresponds to the common SC font layout. It is generally used for display lines set in Large & small caps, such as titles. Forms related to small capitals, such as oldstyle figures, may be included. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'smcp'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.SmallCapitals
member.summary: Replaces 'traditional' Chinese or Japanese forms with the corresponding 'simplified' forms. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'smpl'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.SimplifiedForms
member.summary: In addition to, or instead of, stylistic alternatives of individual glyphs (see 'salt' feature), some fonts may contain sets of stylistic variant glyphs corresponding to portions of the character set, such as multiple variants for lowercase letters in a Latin font. Glyphs in stylistic sets may be designed to harmonise visually, interract in particular ways, or otherwise work together. Examples of fonts including stylistic sets are Zapfino Linotype and Adobe's Poetica. Individual features numbered sequentially with the tag name convention 'ss01' 'ss02' 'ss03' . 'ss20' provide a mechanism for glyphs in these sets to be associated via GSUB lookup indexes to default forms and to each other, and for users to select from available stylistic sets Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss01'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet1
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss02'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet2
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss03'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet3
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss04'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet4
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss05'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet5
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss06'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet6
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss07'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet7
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss08'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet8
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss09'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet9
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss10'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet10
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss11'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet11
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss12'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet12
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss13'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet13
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss14'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet14
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss15'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet15
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss16'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet16
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss17'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet17
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss18'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet18
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss19'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet19
member.summary: See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss20'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.StylisticSet20
member.summary: May replace a default glyph with a subscript glyph, or it may combine a glyph substitution with positioning adjustments for proper placement. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'subs'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Subscript
member.summary: Replaces lining or oldstyle figures with superior figures (primarily for footnote indication), and replaces lowercase letters with superior letters (primarily for abbreviated French titles). Equivalent OpenType tag: 'sups'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Superscript
member.summary: Replaces default character glyphs with corresponding swash glyphs. Note that there may be more than one swash alternate for a given character. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'swsh'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Swash
member.summary: Replaces the default glyphs with corresponding forms designed specifically for titling. These may be all-capital and/or larger on the body, and adjusted for viewing at larger sizes. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'titl'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Titling
member.summary: Replaces 'simplified' Japanese kanji forms with the corresponding 'traditional' forms. This is equivalent to the Traditional Forms feature, but explicitly limited to the traditional forms considered proper for use in personal names (as many as 205 glyphs in some fonts). Equivalent OpenType tag: 'tnam'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.TraditionalNameForms
member.summary: Replaces figure glyphs set on proportional widths with corresponding glyphs set on uniform (tabular) widths. Tabular widths will generally be the default, but this cannot be safely assumed. Of course this feature would not be present in monospaced designs. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'tnum'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.TabularFigures
member.summary: Replaces 'simplified' Chinese hanzi or Japanese kanji forms with the corresponding 'traditional' forms. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'trad'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.TraditionalForms
member.summary: Replaces glyphs on other widths with glyphs set on widths of one third of an em. The characters involved are normally figures and some forms of punctuation. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'twid'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.ThirdWidths
member.summary: Maps upper- and lowercase letters to a mixed set of lowercase and small capital forms, resulting in a single case alphabet (for an example of unicase, see the Emigre type family Filosofia). The letters substituted may vary from font to font, as appropriate to the design. If aligning to the x-height, smallcap glyphs may be substituted, or specially designed unicase forms might be used. Substitutions might also include specially designed figures. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'unic'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.Unicase
member.summary: Allows the user to change from the default 0 to a slashed form. Some fonts contain both a default form of zero, and an alternative form which uses a diagonal slash through the counter. Especially in condensed designs, it can be difficult to distinguish between 0 and O (zero and capital O) in any situation where capitals and lining figures may be arbitrarily mixed. Equivalent OpenType tag: 'zero'

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFeatureTag.SlashedZero
member.summary: No documentation.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ScriptShapes
member.summary: Indicates additional shaping requirements for text.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ScriptShapes.Default
member.summary: Indicates that there is no additional shaping requirements for text. Text is shaped with the writing system default behavior.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ScriptShapes.NoVisual
member.summary: Indicates that text should leave no visible control or format control characters.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.BreakCondition
member.summary: Indicates the condition at the edges of inline object or text used to determine line-breaking behavior.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.Neutral
member.summary: Indicates whether a break is allowed by determining the condition of the neighboring text span or inline object.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.CanBreak
member.summary: Indicates that a line break is allowed, unless overruled by the condition of the neighboring text span or inline object, either prohibited by a "may not break" condition or forced by a "must break" condition.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.MayNotBreak
member.summary: Indicates that there should be no line break, unless overruled by a "must break" condition from the neighboring text span or inline object.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.MustBreak
member.summary: Indicates that the line break must happen, regardless of the condition of the adjacent text span or inline object.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.NumberSubstitutionMethod
member.summary: Specifies how to apply number substitution on digits and related punctuation.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.NumberSubstitutionMethod.FromCulture
member.summary: Specifies that the substitution method should be determined based on the LOCALE_IDIGITSUBSTITUTION value of the specified text culture.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.NumberSubstitutionMethod.Contextual
member.summary: If the culture is Arabic or Persian, specifies that the number shapes depend on the context. Either traditional or nominal number shapes are used, depending on the nearest preceding strong character or (if there is none) the reading direction of the paragraph.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.NumberSubstitutionMethod.None
member.summary: Specifies that code points 0x30-0x39 are always rendered as nominal numeral shapes (ones of the European number), that is, no substitution is performed.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.NumberSubstitutionMethod.National
member.summary: Specifies that numbers are rendered using the national number shapes as specified by the LOCALE_SNATIVEDIGITS value of the specified text culture.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.NumberSubstitutionMethod.Traditional
member.summary: Specifies that numbers are rendered using the traditional shapes for the specified culture. For most cultures, this is the same as NativeNational. However, NativeNational results in Latin numbers for some Arabic cultures, whereasDWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD_TRADITIONAL results in arabic numbers for all Arabic cultures.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextureType
member.summary: Identifies a type of alpha texture.
member.remarks: An alpha texture is a bitmap of alpha values, each representing opacity of a pixel or subpixel.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextureType.Aliased1x1
member.summary: Specifies an alpha texture for aliased text rendering (that is, each pixel is either fully opaque or fully transparent), with one byte per pixel.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextureType.Cleartype3x1
member.summary: Specifies an alpha texture for ClearType text rendering, with three bytes per pixel in the horizontal dimension and one byte per pixel in the vertical dimension.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontFamily.FamilyNames
member.summary: Creates a localized strings object that contains the family names for the font family, indexed by locale name.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics
member.summary: The DWRITE_FONT_METRICS structure specifies the metrics that are applicable to all glyphs within the font face.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.DesignUnitsPerEm
member.summary: The number of font design units per em unit. Font files use their own coordinate system of font design units. A font design unit is the smallest measurable unit in the em square, an imaginary square that is used to size and align glyphs. The concept of em square is used as a reference scale factor when defining font size and device transformation semantics. The size of one em square is also commonly used to compute the paragraph identation value.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.Ascent
member.summary: The ascent value of the font face in font design units. Ascent is the distance from the top of font character alignment box to the English baseline.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.Descent
member.summary: The descent value of the font face in font design units. Descent is the distance from the bottom of font character alignment box to the English baseline.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.LineGap
member.summary: The line gap in font design units. Recommended additional white space to add between lines to improve legibility. The recommended line spacing (baseline-to-baseline distance) is the sum of ascent, descent, and lineGap. The line gap is usually positive or zero but can be negative, in which case the recommended line spacing is less than the height of the character alignment box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.CapHeight
member.summary: The cap height value of the font face in font design units. Cap height is the distance from the English baseline to the top of a typical English capital. Capital "H" is often used as a reference character for the purpose of calculating the cap height value.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.XHeight
member.summary: The x-height value of the font face in font design units. x-height is the distance from the English baseline to the top of lowercase letter "x", or a similar lowercase character.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.UnderlinePosition
member.summary: The underline position value of the font face in font design units. Underline position is the position of underline relative to the English baseline. The value is usually made negative in order to place the underline below the baseline.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.UnderlineThickness
member.summary: The suggested underline thickness value of the font face in font design units.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.StrikethroughPosition
member.summary: The strikethrough position value of the font face in font design units. Strikethrough position is the position of strikethrough relative to the English baseline. The value is usually made positive in order to place the strikethrough above the baseline.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.StrikethroughThickness
member.summary: The suggested strikethrough thickness value of the font face in font design units.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics
member.summary: Specifies the metrics of an individual glyph. The units depend on how the metrics are obtained.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.LeftSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the X offset from the glyph origin to the left edge of the black box. The glyph origin is the current horizontal writing position. A negative value means the black box extends to the left of the origin (often true for lowercase italic 'f').

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.AdvanceWidth
member.summary: Specifies the X offset from the origin of the current glyph to the origin of the next glyph when writing horizontally.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.RightSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the X offset from the right edge of the black box to the origin of the next glyph when writing horizontally. The value is negative when the right edge of the black box overhangs the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.TopSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the vertical offset from the vertical origin to the top of the black box. Thus, a positive value adds whitespace whereas a negative value means the glyph overhangs the top of the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.AdvanceHeight
member.summary: Specifies the Y offset from the vertical origin of the current glyph to the vertical origin of the next glyph when writing vertically. Note that the term "origin" by itself denotes the horizontal origin. The vertical origin is different. Its Y coordinate is specified by verticalOriginY value, and its X coordinate is half the advanceWidth to the right of the horizontal origin.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.BottomSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the vertical distance from the bottom edge of the black box to the advance height. This is positive when the bottom edge of the black box is within the layout box, or negative when the bottom edge of black box overhangs the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphMetrics.VerticalOriginY
member.summary: Specifies the Y coordinate of a glyph's vertical origin, in the font's design coordinate system. The y coordinate of a glyph's vertical origin is the sum of the glyph's top side bearing and the top (that is, yMax) of the glyph's bounding box.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphOffset
member.summary: The optional adjustment to a glyph's position.
member.remarks: An glyph offset changes the position of a glyph without affecting the pen position. Offsets are in logical, pre-transform units.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphOffset.AdvanceOffset
member.summary: The offset in the advance direction of the run. A positive advance offset moves the glyph to the right (in pre-transform coordinates) if the run is left-to-right or to the left if the run is right-to-left.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.GlyphOffset.AscenderOffset
member.summary: The offset in the ascent direction, that is, the direction ascenders point. A positive ascender offset moves the glyph up (in pre-transform coordinates). A negative ascender offset moves the glyph down.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Matrix
member.summary: The DWRITE_MATRIX structure specifies the graphics transform to be applied to rendered glyphs.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Matrix.M11
member.summary: A value indicating the horizontal scaling / cosine of rotation.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Matrix.M12
member.summary: A value indicating the vertical shear / sine of rotation.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Matrix.M21
member.summary: A value indicating the horizontal shear / negative sine of rotation.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Matrix.M22
member.summary: A value indicating the vertical scaling / cosine of rotation.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Matrix.Dx
member.summary: A value indicating the horizontal shift (always orthogonal regardless of rotation).

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Matrix.Dy
member.summary: A value indicating the vertical shift (always orthogonal regardless of rotation.)

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TypographicFeatures
member.summary: Contains a set of typographic features to be applied during text shaping.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TypographicFeatures.Features
member.summary: A reference to a structure that specifies properties used to identify and execute typographic features in the font.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TypographicFeatures.FeatureCount
member.summary: A value that indicates the number of features being applied to a font face.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Trimming
member.summary: Specifies the trimming option for text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Trimming.Granularity
member.summary: A value that specifies the text granularity used to trim text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Trimming.Delimiter
member.summary: A character code used as the delimiter that signals the beginning of the portion of text to be preserved. Most useful for path ellipsis, where the delimiter would be a slash.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Trimming.DelimiterCount
member.summary: A value that indicates how many occurrences of the delimiter to step back.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ScriptAnalysis
member.summary: Stores the association of text and its writing system script, as well as some display attributes.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ScriptAnalysis.Script
member.summary: The zero-based index representation of writing system script.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ScriptAnalysis.Shapes
member.summary: A value that indicates additional shaping requirement of text.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ShapingTextProperties
member.summary: Shaping output properties for an output glyph.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ShapingTextProperties.IsShapedAlone
member.summary: Indicates that the glyph is shaped alone.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ShapingTextProperties.Reserved
member.summary: Reserved for future use.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Underline
member.summary: Contains information about the width, thickness, offset, run height, reading direction, and flow direction of an underline.
member.remarks: All coordinates are in device independent pixels (DIPs).

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Underline.Width
member.summary: A value that indicates the width of the underline, measured parallel to the baseline.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Underline.Thickness
member.summary: A value that indicates the thickness of the underline, measured perpendicular to the baseline.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Underline.Offset
member.summary: A value that indicates the offset of the underline from the baseline. A positive offset represents a position below the baseline (away from the text) and a negative offset is above (toward the text).

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Underline.RunHeight
member.summary: A value that indicates the height of the tallest run where the underline is applied.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Underline.ReadingDirection
member.summary: A value that indicates the reading direction of the text associated with the underline. This value is used to interpret whether the width value runs horizontally or vertically.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Underline.FlowDirection
member.summary: A value that indicates the flow direction of the text associated with the underline. This value is used to interpret whether the thickness value advances top to bottom, left to right, or right to left.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Underline.LocaleName
member.summary: An array of characters which contains the locale of the text that the underline is being drawn under. For example, in vertical text, the underline belongs on the left for Chinese but on the right for Japanese.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Underline.MeasuringMode
member.summary: The measuring mode can be useful to the renderer to determine how underlines are rendered, such as rounding the thickness to a whole pixel in GDI-compatible modes.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Strikethrough
member.summary: Contains information regarding the size and placement of strikethroughs. All coordinates are in device independent pixels (DIPs).

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Strikethrough.Width
member.summary: A value that indicates the width of the strikethrough, measured parallel to the baseline.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Strikethrough.Thickness
member.summary: A value that indicates the thickness of the strikethrough, measured perpendicular to the baseline.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Strikethrough.Offset
member.summary: A value that indicates the offset of the strikethrough from the baseline. A positive offset represents a position below the baseline and a negative offset is above. Typically, the offset will be negative.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Strikethrough.ReadingDirection
member.summary: Reading direction of the text associated with the strikethrough. This value is used to interpret whether the width value runs horizontally or vertically.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Strikethrough.FlowDirection
member.summary: Flow direction of the text associated with the strikethrough. This value is used to interpret whether the thickness value advances top to bottom, left to right, or right to left.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Strikethrough.LocaleName
member.summary: An array of characters containing the locale of the text that is the strikethrough is being drawn over.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.Strikethrough.MeasuringMode
member.summary: The measuring mode can be useful to the renderer to determine how underlines are rendered, such as rounding the thickness to a whole pixel in GDI-compatible modes.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.LineMetrics
member.summary: Contains information about a formatted line of text.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.Length
member.summary: The number of text positions in the text line. This includes any trailing whitespace and newline characters.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.TrailingWhitespaceLength
member.summary: The number of whitespace positions at the end of the text line. Newline sequences are considered whitespace.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.NewlineLength
member.summary: The number of characters in the newline sequence at the end of the text line. If the count is zero, then the text line was either wrapped or it is the end of the text.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.Height
member.summary: The height of the text line.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.Baseline
member.summary: The distance from the top of the text line to its baseline.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.IsTrimmed
member.summary: The line is trimmed.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ClusterMetrics
member.summary: Contains information about a glyph cluster.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ClusterMetrics.Width
member.summary: The total advance width of all glyphs in the cluster.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ClusterMetrics.Length
member.summary: The number of text positions in the cluster.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ClusterMetrics.CanWrapLineAfter
member.summary: Indicates whether a line can be broken right after the cluster.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ClusterMetrics.IsWhitespace
member.summary: Indicates whether the cluster corresponds to a whitespace character.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ClusterMetrics.IsNewline
member.summary: Indicates whether the cluster corresponds to a newline character.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ClusterMetrics.IsSoftHyphen
member.summary: Indicates whether the cluster corresponds to a soft hyphen character.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ClusterMetrics.IsRightToLeft
member.summary: Indicates whether the cluster is read from right to left.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.ClusterMetrics.Padding
member.summary: Reserved for future use.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics
member.summary: Contains the metrics associated with text after layout. All coordinates are in device independent pixels (DIPs).

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Left
member.summary: A value that indicates the left-most point of formatted text relative to the layout box, while excluding any glyph overhang.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Top
member.summary: A value that indicates the top-most point of formatted text relative to the layout box, while excluding any glyph overhang.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Width
member.summary: A value that indicates the width of the formatted text, while ignoring trailing whitespace at the end of each line.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.WidthIncludingTrailingWhitespace
member.summary: The width of the formatted text, taking into account the trailing whitespace at the end of each line.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Height
member.summary: The height of the formatted text. The height of an empty string is set to the same value as that of the default font.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.LayoutWidth
member.summary: The initial width given to the layout. It can be either larger or smaller than the text content width, depending on whether the text was wrapped.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.LayoutHeight
member.summary: Initial height given to the layout. Depending on the length of the text, it may be larger or smaller than the text content height.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.MaxBidiReorderingDepth
member.summary: The maximum reordering count of any line of text, used to calculate the most number of hit-testing boxes needed. If the layout has no bidirectional text, or no text at all, the minimum level is 1.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.LineCount
member.summary: No documentation.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics
member.summary: Contains properties describing the geometric measurement of an application-defined inline object.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.Width
member.summary: The width of the inline object.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.Height
member.summary: The height of the inline object.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.Baseline
member.summary: The distance from the top of the object to the point where it is lined up with the adjacent text. If the baseline is at the bottom, then baseline simply equals height.

member.name: P:SharpDX.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.SupportsSideways
member.summary: A Boolean flag that indicates whether the object is to be placed upright or alongside the text baseline for vertical text.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics
member.summary: Indicates how much any visible DIPs (device independent pixels) overshoot each side of the layout or inline objects.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics.Left
member.summary: The distance from the left-most visible DIP to its left alignment edge.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics.Top
member.summary: The distance from the top-most visible DIP to its top alignment edge.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics.Right
member.summary: The distance from the right-most visible DIP to its right alignment edge.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics.Bottom
member.summary: The distance from the bottom-most visible DIP to its lower alignment edge.

member.name: T:SharpDX.DirectWrite.HitTestMetrics
member.summary: Describes the region obtained by a hit test.

member.name: F:SharpDX.DirectWrite.HitTestMetrics.TextPosition
member.summary: The first text position within the hit region.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.AlphaMode
member.summary: Specifies how the alpha value of a bitmap or render target should be treated.
member.remarks: The D2D1_ALPHA_MODE enumeration is used with the enumeration to specify the alpha mode of a render target or bitmap. Different render targets and bitmaps support different alpha modes. For a list, see {{Supported Pixel Formats and Alpha Modes}}. The Differences Between Straight and Premultiplied Alpha When describing an RGBA color using straight alpha, the alpha value of the color is stored in the alpha channel. For example, to describe a red color that is 60% opaque, you'd use the following values: (255, 0, 0, 255 * 0.6) = (255, 0, 0, 153). The 255 value indicates full red, and 153 (which is 60 percent of 255) indicates that the color should have an opacity of 60 percent. When describing an RGBA color using premultiplied alpha, each color is multiplied by the alpha value: (255 * 0.6, 0 * 0.6, 0 * 0.6, 255 * 0.6) = (153, 0, 0, 153). Regardless of the alpha mode of the render target, values are always interpreted as straight alpha. For example, when specifying the color of an for use with a bitmap that uses the premultiplied alpha mode, you'd specify the color just as you would if the bitmap used straight alpha. When you paint with the brush, Direct2D translates the color to the destination format for you. Alpha Mode for Render Targets Regardless of the alpha mode setting, a render target's contents support transparency. For example, if you draw a partially transparent red rectangle with a render target with an alpha mode of D2D1_ALPHA_MODE_IGNORE, the rectangle will appear pink (if the background is white), as you might expect. If you draw a partially transparent red rectangle when the alpha mode is D2D1_ALPHA_MODE_PREMULTIPLIED, the rectangle will appear pink (assuming the background is white) and you can see through it to whatever is behind the render target. This is useful when using a to render to a transparent window or when using an compatible render target (a render targeted created by the {{CreateCompatibleRenderTarget}} method) to create a bitmap that supports transparency. ClearType and Alpha Modes If you specify an alpha mode other than D2D1_ALPHA_MODE_IGNORE for a render target, the text antialiasing mode automatically changes from {{D2D1_TEXT_ANTIALIAS_MODE CLEARTYPE}} to D2D1_TEXT_ANTIALIAS_MODE GRAYSCALE. (When you specify an alpha mode of D2D1_ALPHA_MODE_UNKNOWN, Direct2D sets the alpha for you depending on the type of render target. For a list of what the D2D1_ALPHA_MODE_UNKNOWN setting resolves to for each render target, see the {{Supported Pixel Formats and Alpha Modes}} overview.) You can use the {{SetTextAntialiasMode}} method to change the text antialias mode back to {{D2D1_TEXT_ANTIALIAS_MODE CLEARTYPE}}, but rendering ClearType text to a transparent surface can create unpredictable results. If you want to render ClearType text to an transparent render target, we recommend that you use one of the following two techniques. Use the {{PushAxisAlignedClip}} method to clip the render target to the area where the text will be rendered, then call the {{Clear}} method and specify an opaque color, then render your text. Use {{DrawRectangle}} to draw an opaque rectangle behind the area where the text will be rendered.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Unknown
member.summary: The alpha value might not be meaningful.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Premultiplied
member.summary: The alpha value has been premultiplied. Each color is first scaled by the alpha value. The alpha value itself is the same in both straight and premultiplied alpha. Typically, no color channel value is greater than the alpha channel value. If a color channel value in a premultiplied format is greater than the alpha channel, the standard source-over blending math results in an additive blend.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Straight
member.summary: The alpha value has not been premultiplied. The alpha channel indicates the transparency of the color.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Ignore
member.summary: The alpha value is ignored.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.Gamma
member.summary: Specifies which gamma is used for interpolation.
member.remarks: Interpolating in a linear gamma space (D2D1_GAMMA_1_0) can avoid changes in perceived brightness caused by the effect of gamma correction in spaces where the gamma is not 1.0, such as the default sRGB color space, where the gamma is 2.2. For an example of the differences between these two blending modes, consider the following illustration, which shows two gradients, each of which blends from red to blue to green: ? Illustration of two gradients from red to blue to green, blended by using sRGB gamma and linear-gamma ? The first gradient is interpolated linearly in the space of the render target (sRGB in this case), and one can see the dark bands between each color. The second gradient uses a gamma-correct linear interpolation, and thus does not exhibit the same variations in brightness.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.Gamma.StandardRgb
member.summary: Interpolation is performed in the standard RGB (sRGB) gamma.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.Gamma.Linear
member.summary: Interpolation is performed in the linear-gamma color space.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.OpacityMaskContent
member.summary: Describes whether an opacity mask contains graphics or text. Direct2D uses this information to determine which gamma space to use when blending the opacity mask.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.OpacityMaskContent.Graphics
member.summary: The opacity mask contains graphics. The opacity mask is blended in the gamma 2.2 color space.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.OpacityMaskContent.TextNatural
member.summary: The opacity mask contains non-GDI text. The gamma space used for blending is obtained from the render target's text rendering parameters. ().

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.OpacityMaskContent.TextGdiCompatible
member.summary: The opacity mask contains text rendered using the GDI-compatible rendering mode. The opacity mask is blended using the gamma for GDI rendering.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.ExtendMode
member.summary: Specifies how a brush paints areas outside of its normal content area.
member.remarks: For an , the brush's content is the brush's bitmap. For an , the brush's content area is the gradient axis. For an , the brush's content is the area within the gradient ellipse. For an example, see the {{Draw Extend Mode Example}}.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.ExtendMode.Clamp
member.summary: Repeat the edge pixels of the brush's content for all regions outside the normal content area.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.ExtendMode.Wrap
member.summary: Repeat the brush's content.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.ExtendMode.Mirror
member.summary: The same as D2D1_EXTEND_MODE_WRAP, except that alternate tiles of the brush's content are flipped. (The brush's normal content is drawn untransformed.)

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.AntialiasMode
member.summary: Specifies how the edges of nontext primitives are rendered.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.AntialiasMode.PerPrimitive
member.summary: Edges are antialiased using the Direct2D per-primitive method of high-quality antialiasing.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.AntialiasMode.Aliased
member.summary: Objects are aliased in most cases. Objects are antialiased only when they are drawn to a render target created by the {{CreateDxgiSurfaceRenderTarget}} method and Direct3D multisampling has been enabled on the backing DirectX Graphics Infrastructure (DXGI) surface.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.TextAntialiasMode
member.summary: Describes the antialiasing mode used for drawing text.
member.remarks: This enumeration is used with the {{SetTextAntialiasMode}} of an to specify how text and glyphs are antialiased. By default, Direct2D renders text in ClearType mode. Factors that can downgrade the default quality to grayscale or aliased: If the value is DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE_ALIASED , then the default text antialiasing mode is aliased. To change the DirectWrite rendering mode of an , use the method. If the value is DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE_OUTLINE, then the default text antialiasing mode is grayscale. If the render target has an alpha channel and is not set to , then the default text antialiasing mode is grayscale. If is called without (and the corresponding {{PopLayer}} has not been called yet), then the default text antialiasing mode is grayscale.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.TextAntialiasMode.Default
member.summary: Use the system default. See Remarks.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.TextAntialiasMode.Cleartype
member.summary: Use ClearType antialiasing.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.TextAntialiasMode.Grayscale
member.summary: Use grayscale antialiasing.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.TextAntialiasMode.Aliased
member.summary: Do not use antialiasing.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.BitmapInterpolationMode
member.summary: Specifies the algorithm that is used when images are scaled or rotated.
member.remarks: To stretch an image, each pixel in the original image must be mapped to a group of pixels in the larger image. To shrink an image, groups of pixels in the original image must be mapped to single pixels in the smaller image. The effectiveness of the algorithms that perform these mappings determines the quality of a scaled image. Algorithms that produce higher-quality scaled images tend to require more processing time. D2D1_BITMAP_INTERPOLATION_MODE_NEAREST_NEIGHBOR provides faster but lower-quality interpolation, while D2D1_BITMAP_INTERPOLATION_MODE_LINEAR provides higher-quality interpolation.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.BitmapInterpolationMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Use the exact color of the nearest bitmap pixel to the current rendering pixel.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.BitmapInterpolationMode.Linear
member.summary: Interpolate a color from the four bitmap pixels that are the nearest to the rendering pixel.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DrawTextOptions
member.summary: Specifies whether text snapping is suppressed or clipping to the layout rectangle is enabled. This enumeration allows a bitwise combination of its member values.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DrawTextOptions.NoSnap
member.summary: Text is not vertically snapped to pixel boundaries. This setting is recommended for text that is being animated.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DrawTextOptions.Clip
member.summary: Text is clipped to the layout rectangle.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DrawTextOptions.None
member.summary: Text is vertically snapped to pixel boundaries and is not clipped to the layout rectangle.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.ArcSize

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.ArcSize.Large

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.CapStyle
member.summary: Describes the shape at the end of a line or segment.
member.remarks: The following illustration shows the available cap styles for lines or segments. The red portion of the line shows the extra area added by the line cap setting. ? Illustration of four cap styles ?

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.CapStyle.Flat
member.summary: A cap that does not extend past the last point of the line. Comparable to cap used for objects other than lines.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.CapStyle.Square
member.summary: Half of a square that has a length equal to the line thickness.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.CapStyle.Round
member.summary: A semicircle that has a diameter equal to the line thickness.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.CapStyle.Triangle
member.summary: An isosceles right triangle whose hypotenuse is equal in length to the thickness of the line.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DashStyle
member.summary: Describes the sequence of dashes and gaps in a stroke.
member.remarks: The following illustration shows several available dash styles. For more information, see the {{Stroke Style Example}}. ? Illustration of available dash styles ?

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Solid
member.summary: A solid line with no breaks.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Dash
member.summary: A dash followed by a gap of equal length. The dash and the gap are each twice as long as the stroke thickness. The equivalent dash array for D2D1_DASH_STYLE_DASH is {2, 2}.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Dot
member.summary: A dot followed by a longer gap. The equivalent dash array for D2D1_DASH_STYLE_DOT is {0, 2}.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.DashDot
member.summary: A dash, followed by a gap, followed by a dot, followed by another gap. The equivalent dash array for D2D1_DASH_STYLE_DASH_DOT is {2, 2, 0, 2}.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.DashDotDot
member.summary: A dash, followed by a gap, followed by a dot, followed by another gap, followed by another dot, followed by another gap. The equivalent dash array for D2D1_DASH_STYLE_DASH_DOT_DOT is {2, 2, 0, 2, 0, 2}.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Custom
member.summary: The dash pattern is specified by an array of floating-point values.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.LineJoin
member.summary: Describes the shape that joins two lines or segments.
member.remarks: A miter limit affects how sharp miter joins are allowed to be. If the line join style is D2D1_LINE_JOIN_MITER_OR_BEVEL, then the join will be mitered with regular angular vertices if it doesn't extend beyond the miter limit; otherwise, the line join will be beveled. The following illustration shows different line join settings for the same stroked path geometry. For more information, see {{Stroke Style Example}}. ? Illustration of line join settings ?

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.LineJoin.Miter
member.summary: Regular angular vertices.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.LineJoin.Bevel
member.summary: Beveled vertices.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.LineJoin.Round
member.summary: Rounded vertices.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.LineJoin.MiterOrBevel
member.summary: Regular angular vertices unless the join would extend beyond the miter limit; otherwise, beveled vertices.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.CombineMode
member.summary: Specifies the different methods by which two geometries can be combined.
member.remarks: The following illustration shows the different geometry combine modes. ? Illustration of two geometries and the resulting shapes after various geometry combine modes ?

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.CombineMode.Union
member.summary: The two regions are combined by taking the union of both. Given two geometries, A and B, the resulting geometry is geometry A + geometry B.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.CombineMode.Intersect
member.summary: The two regions are combined by taking their intersection. The new area consists of the overlapping region between the two geometries.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.CombineMode.Xor
member.summary: The two regions are combined by taking the area that exists in the first region but not the second and the area that exists in the second region but not the first. Given two geometries, A and B, the new region consists of (A-B) + (B-A).

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.CombineMode.Exclude
member.summary: The second region is excluded from the first. Given two geometries, A and B, the area of geometry B is removed from the area of geometry A, producing a region that is A-B.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation.Unknown

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation.Disjoint

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation.IsContained
member.summary: The instance geometry is entirely contained by the passed-in geometry.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation.Contains
member.summary: The instance geometry entirely contains the passed-in geometry.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.GeometryRelation.Overlap
member.summary: The two geometries overlap but neither completely contains the other.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Direct2D1.GeometrySimplificationOption.Lines
